												Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising is one of those gems that is overlooked by most players.  Personally I think the way to get the most out of this game though is running multi-player Co-op.This is no Call of Duty or Medal of Honor shoot 'em up, but rather a tactical combat simulator.  If you are a solo player I would probably skip this title.  However if you like to roleplay and really get into your job, then team up with up to three others and run this game in multi-player campaign mode (Co-op). There are four roles to choose from. Engineer, Medic, Sniper and Squad Leader.  There is only one squad leader and he sets up and calls out the waypoints and strategies through the missions.  The game can be a bit glitchy at times, but the fun factor far outweighs the technical glitches.  The first mission is probably the worst, so if you pick up this game don't let the beginning stop you.  By the third mission you will be wading through the foliage calling out targets for your sniper while your engineer sets some demo up on an enemy APC.  I cannot emphasize enough that this game is best played with others and is definitely not a solo affair.  You will need to use 3rd party software for headset chat.  You will need to use a headset as well as the in game communication is very poor.I always played Squad Leader, as I was the host for our game sessions.  One of the most memorable moments in this game for me was when our sniper got pinned down behind a wall and was getting hammered by a .50 cal from an enemy technical.  I sent in the engineer with this heavy weapon and before he reached the wall he went down hard.  He was still alive so I instructed the medic to lend support to the engineer while I drew fire from the technical.  The screaming going on over the headset was intense.  The medic got the engineer back on his feet and behind the wall while our sniper bugged out of the area.  I was getting attention form that .50 cal and hiding behind a tree and was also drawing fire from some infantry that heard the ruckus and started closing in on my position.  Just when I figured that I was going down the technical blew up thanks to our engineer's heavy weapon and the inantry closing in on my position started dropping like flies from our sniper.  We were back in business doing what we did best. When it comes right down to it, it's times like this that I game for.  I would highly suggest this title to anyone that likes to game with friends.  Operation Flashpoint: Red River is even better and provides a smoother ride.  If you can pick this title up on a steam sale with Red River I wouldn't hesitate.

												Underrated game in my mind. I played this originally on the Xbox 360 back when it released, then later on purchased it on PC within a Codemasters Bundle that was on sale.A lot of people like to say negative things about this game, but honestly, I really enjoyed it. I thoroughly enjoy realistic tactical shooters and milsims, and this game ranks high on the list of available games. That's not to say it doesn't have its problems. The AI isn't the best (although there is a mod to remedy this), and the resolutions are restricted to 1280x1024 as the highest option. To fix this, you'll need to download another .exe and replace the one in the game installation folder. The guides section has this fix explained in detail with links to the file.The game has a great campaign, and in fact, it's easily one of the best single-player campaigns I've experienced; very enjoyable and expansive missions that feel very immersive and challenging in a very unforgiving manner. Screw up just a tiny bit, and it'll cost you greatly. There's a few side missions available independently from the campaign, plus you can download a ton of mission packs off of modding websites to further enhance the single-player longevity.Multiplayer is no longer officially supported, which is unfortunate, however, there is a very simple workaround. Simply use Gameranger and host LAN games and you'll be completely set. Now onto my gripes. These two issues are single handedly my biggest problems with this game, and if they weren't there, this would easily be one of the top military tactical shooters out there, and would be something I'd put a LOT more time into. These issues are FOV (Field of View) and mouse acceleration. Absolutely unforgivable to not have proper support in these areas. The FOV is locked at around 60, which is horrid. There's no way to change it, at all, by any means. Now, I did get used to it, and didn't let it ruin my experience too much, and I'll get to that in a second. As for mouse acceleration, once again, no fix available. You're stuck with it, and it sucks. In this regard, playing with a controller is actually superior, although your aim will undoubtedly suffer from it. Now if it was one or the other, it wouldn't be that much of a problem. For example, if you could increase your FOV to around 90, but the mouse acceleration was still present, it would still be annoying, but it would be less annoying. If there was no mouse acceleration, but the FOV was still locked at 60, once again, less annoying. But the two combined.... just, it's terrible, and as I said, unforgivable in a PC game. Aside from that, this is easily one of the most optimized games I've ever played. The performance is outstanding, especially on any PC stronger than an Xbox 360. I mean think about it, last gen consoles could run this game. Naturally people would compare this game to Arma, and in the realm of performance, there's no comparison. The EGO Engine is outstanding, and the visuals still hold up well even today. In fact, I'd compare the visuals to the newly released SQUAD, and in some ways, it even looks better. To be completely honest, after playing this game through again just recently, I'd say it's very similar to SQUAD in gameplay style, and even the HUD elements (compass, weapon selection menu, etc.), only it has a very detailed single-player experience.To rap things up, it's an excellent game, hampered down by two glaring issues that can be mitigated if you play this game the way it was designed... as a console game. What I mean by this, plug in your Xbox 360 controller, sit back farther than usual, and the FOV will be somewhat more tolerable, and mouse acceleration will be a non-issue since you're not even using a mouse. If you can get past those two issues, you're in for a great military shooter experience. Calling in artillery and mortor fire is easily one of the most satisfying things you can do in this game, among many other things. So with that in mind, given its price, I'd recommend it. Plus with Steams ability to refund, you'll be able to experience enough within 2 hours to determine whether or not you'll want to issue one.

												Being pretty different from the original Operation Flashpoint, Dragon Rising is still a decent game. Compared to the first game and the Arma series, it is friendlier and is a great game for people not familiar with "realistic" shooters, because it nicely displays modern combat, better than most military shooters nowadays. The game's world is a single location, a big island, and unlike similar games there's no draw distance limit. Despite this the graphics are nice and well-optimized (for 2009). The story is nothing special and is pretty short, but the missions are fun. You drive vehicles, command your squad, use different firearms modeled after the real ones; a level editor is also included, as in the game's predecessor. The game's development probably was pushed by the publisher, so it can feel unpolished, there's cut content (some of it can still be found in the game's files), some annoying bugs, and not so good AI. I recommend Dragon Rising if you want a game that balances between "Hollywood action" (à la Call of Duty) and military simulations (like Arma).

												First of all, let me be clear--IMO all positive and negative reviews on Steam stand CORRECT. Yes, this game is just as good as people claimed, and as aweful as some have criticized.Skip to the end for TL;DRThis game is the bad brother of ARMA, but good enough to truly realize what CoD MW1 could have been on a next level of size, depth, and lethality. And I think a few things should be covered so that those who read on will know what to expect. note* I still have not dived myself into mission editor and not enough players for PvP, so no comments on these.Missions--Campaign is similar to CoD, the missions do cover some of the most basic of types: ambush, night raid, charge and hold town, diversionary strike (support)...etc. Each mission would be a blend of these, so expect some time to be invested, especially if you do take things carefully. These missions are quite standard and relatable to what most contemporary armies would do, and yet both CoD and newer Battlefield doesn't quite capture the size and freedom that OFDR offers. The enemy do go on a patrol path, with another patrol that overlaps to provide constant oversight. It is a very reasonable design that challenges one to think "how can i approach this defense before 12 men start stacking grenades on me?" I truly appreciate this design work, but more on that on the AI behaviour.Size/Gunplay--Since this game is loosely similar to ARMA, semi-open world travel is a key feature. All missions range from medium to large area of terrain. players must travel most of the time on foot to get to objectives. Luckily, the designers have put enough enemies along reasonable key points, hilltops with machine gun nests, and ammo crates to make things more interesting. Pick you routes, plan ahead, use your binoculars to SEE WHERE THINGS ARE, and proceed to walk your own path. No restirctions other than enemy fire, and you will be ambushed if you make a bad move.See the issue is that camoflage in this game works. I am both impressed and traumatized at how enemies can sneak right into your face and shoot your at point blank range. And that is because there is no minimap, no Friend/Foe tags (need this more in shooters), and the bushes are such a well blend of colours especially if the graphics are set to low.While this game is not as hardcore on the simulation side, the sway of the gun when moving, lack of jumping mechanics, and recoil system does give a very hard time to aim, if only I can see. While this may turn some of you away (door on the right, please help yourself), I certainly loved it because i actually felt like firing a gun for the 1st time. Granted, I still have yet tried ARMA 2, but at least OFDR gave me my first time. Taking the stinger from your shoulder also requires loading time, cuz no one ever puts an explosive near their head during bullet fights (do these things blow? if anyone knows plz inform), nd the same goes for putting it back on the shoulder.And to fellow soldiers: please LOOK, then DO. if you don't know what to DO, stop and don't panic, LOOK MORE.AI--their designs can go from baffilngly stupid to insane manhunt machines. They will duck if suppressed, alert if bullets fly by, flee if crushed, and will run a circle to catch you in the back 10min later. They will always spot novice players (like me) before you even see their muzzle flash. And yet, AI teammates will also stand in one spot and receive grenades while you, the leader, try to heal yourself. Im not too experienced in AI mechaincs, so I can't give a full analysis, but just bear in mind that they are very good shots over 300m+, your health doesn't count much across the various difficulties, and they will nail you when given the chance. Try to keep moving in unpredictable directions and keep far away from imminent danger; works alright for me. Multiplayer--please, for the love of God, either hate it and don't play it; love it and Google how to fix it. There are pinned Steam forum posts on how easy it is to register and setup Tunngle. No knowledge on hosting servers, just install, launch and login, find the right OFDR server, and all your friends will be in the same public room. one of you host a LAN game, and everyone just jump in. My experience with coop is delightful--me and my bud had so much fun killing fellow PLA soldiers, getting bullet skinned by PLA soldiers, sneaking around in forests, and hiding behind bushes while the magnificent AI takes care of the rest. Think that says enough?Guns/Characters/Vehicles--When entering coop and single playergames, you get pre-assigned by the game to a 4-men squad. The only thing you can choose is class: stand. rifleman, Spec Ops rifleman, grenadier, engineer (explosives), AT,  sniper, medic, and squad automatic. It covers most classes like Battlefield, but no weapon choices like Battlefield. Quite sad, but I guess Defense budget got cut again. The first player/host will always have to be team leader, thus limiting player weapon choices even further. Luckily enemies do drop standardized weapons from the PLA side, and you can use that method to switch weapons if no ammo crates in the vaccinity.Vehicle numbers and types are also very much lacking: jeeps, APCs, ENEMY tanks, choppers. This is a major disadvantage for OFDR, and I will not smooth this one because it is just that lackluster. Also, since Codemasters have quite deserted this game, it is ironic that the very 1st original OF (later ARMA CWC) has more available mods than this game. Shame...Conclusion--I LOVED this game. My AMD HD6450 can actually run this pretty smooth at 900p (windowed), I had hours of blast on coop with my buddy, and completing the missions are actually a worthwhile experience. I am a diehard coop fan, and this FPS has provided me with enough assets to make a game challenging, walk a whole lot, plan ahead, fail my plan miserably, and try new ways at how to deal with crazy AIs.As for others, please don't buy if the gun sway, heavy recoil is not your type; I understand, after all every boy wants to be laser-aimbot spec Ops. Also, this not not truly open world, lacks modding, very little ingame assets, and bascially no LAN players unless you have friend(s). Since Tunngle is basically hazzle free, please no further b*tching on that, or just be honets about how much you hate CodeMasters, which I won't mind.

												This game.Oh lord, this game.Let's start by saying that my hour count isn't representative. I bought the original retail version of this game 4 years ago, and I've played it for days.Do you like shooters? Do you like them little bit tougher and more tactical, but are you scared of ArmA's complexity and bored of Battlefield's simplicity? If you answered yes to all the questions, then I've got a game for you.Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising, along with its slightly hotter sister Red River is basically a "revival" of sorts of the old series Operation Flashpoint. The concept stays the same since the first game. A tactical military shooter, which throws you into a big, open world and gives you goals. You can either complete them to advance the campaign/mission further, or you can just ♥♥♥♥ around in the big open world with vehicles ranging from jeeps to helicopters.Graphics are really pretty for an open-world sandbox that came out in 2009, albeit a bit brown, the shooting is solid, vehicles handle like real vehicles, albeit a little simplified, enemy AI is actually smart (I've seen enemy soldiers laying supressing fire on my squad, while the rest of them flanked us and attacked us from behind), your AI companions follow your orders well and are capable of handling themselves quite easily (seriously, for the first 30 or so minutes, you  will  depend on these guys, they saved my♥♥♥♥♥♥multiple times even as an experienced player) and the story is quite interesting for a military sandbox.Sounds good? Because it is, but it's  not  perfect. Not at all. My first major gripe with this game is the tutorial. Or the lack of it. The game throws you into a mission without any explanation of the basic controls, and you better have Google opened on the Steam browser, because you will have to look up controls for yourself. The second big problem is the artillery support the HQ can give you. It makes the game way too easy sometimes. Seriously, you can just call in a barrage 90% of the time and it will solve your issues instantly.Third (more of a nitpick than anything though) issue I have with this game are the aforementioned team-mates. While their AI is good, they sometimes do nothing until you give orders. Which can be a huge problem if you get downed, because the medic  will  not help you by himself sometimes.Over all, I recommend this game. It's dirt cheap, and great fun when you get used to the strange controls, harsh weapon physics and brown-ish graphics.8/10, this game along with its sis is a great sequel to a masterpiece of a game.

												An oldie but a goodie. Set in an alternate 2011, you play as various Marine fireteam leaders, part of a USMC task force dispatched to liberate the fictional Russian Island of Skira which has been occupied by the PLA. AKA the Peoples Liberation Army. AKA the Chinese. If you have played this game's sequel on PC (Operation Flashpoint Red River), you will be happy to hear this title escapes the windows live integration with which it is burdened. Thank God! I remember playing this when it first came out on the XBOX 360 and even though I may be a little nostalgic over this title, I think it defiantly holds up and would still toughly recommend it, even at non sale prices, if you are looking for a solid tactical shooter. Though keep in mind you will pretty much be buying a campaign at this point as the multiplayer is dead.The connection to and comparison with the ARMA series is kind of unavoidable and while this game lacks a lot of what made up even ARMA II, it also excels in many respects too. Compared to the ARMA series, the multiplayer was never really heavily populated and lacked some depth. The other major point of comparison is that of mod support. Something which has kept the ARMA series going strong throughout those game's life cycles has been the ability to mod the ever loving♥♥♥♥♥♥out of those games. This is something Operation Flashpoint Dragon Rising (OF DR) lacks and so its replay value is greatly diminished, something which contributed to its sharp drop off in players. Though there have been some mods developed for the game since its release, these have been somewhat limited in scope compared to many mods you can find for ARMA.However it is unfair to characterise this game solely by its negative aspects compared to the ARMA series. There are many elements in OF DR which were done very well and are still better that the ARMA series even to this day (ARMA III). One of these elements is the AI. I am sure many of you are familiar with the frustrating AI in the ARMA series and while the OP DR AI is not perfect, it achieved in 2009 what we can only dream the AI in ARMA was like today. They use cover, support each other, as well as you, make intelligent call outs and assault buildings very effectively to name a few things. The only major downside I found with the AI in this game is that they often do not seem to be able to engage enemy infantry past 200m, though this is rarely a real problem. Other aspects in which OP DR surpasses ARMA include the better modelled vehicle interiors and fantastic character animations. I particularly love the reload animation for the launchers which I have never seen anything which comes close in any other game.Releasing in 2009, though a little dated, its graphics still hold up. The character and weapon models are very good and the terrain is beautiful. Throughout the campaign you are given a number of different weapons with various different attachments to play with and the sound design for all of them is quite excellent. The campaign takes place on the fictional island of Skira (a faithful recreation of the real Kiska Island) and features a wide variety of missions including; platoon sized assaults in the day as well as the night, infiltration, rescue and assassination/sabotage missions all of which are very fun in their own way. Despite the game being on console it plays perfectly on PC and the need to adapt the control scheme to consoles resulted in smooth and intuitive gameplay. The highlight of which is the command wheel. This command wheel is how you command your aforementioned AI and is very simple to navigate while at the same time, offering a lot of depth to the player in commanding how he wants his squad to act. This includes; movement, fire discipline, formations and spread to name a few.I did however have a few other issues with the game though none are major things and some had been in hardly any games in 2009 and so could be considered unfair criticisms but this is looking back from today’s tactical shooters. One issue I had was the limited weapon handling the game gives you regarding ranging and aiming your weapons. What I mean by this is that when using iron sights, there is no way to adjust zero and the game doesn't tell you your weapon’s zero with any sight or scope. Though this is less of an issue with scopes as there are often mil-dots to adjust off. When using some sights like the ACOG, it is also impossible to use the backup iron sights on top of the sighting system, making it tricky to engage targets close in. The last complaint I have with the game is that it is only possible to change the weapon/equipment in your hands or give an order using the command wheel while stationary. Although you can give a limited amount of orders on the map, this often put me in the position of having to stop dead while under enemy fire to execute an action or issue an order.Despite the small number of criticisms I have of this game, it is one of my all-time favourites. Overall as I said at the top, I would highly recommend this game if you are interested in the tactical shooter genre and want to play an interesting and fun campaign outside of the ARMA series.

												This is a tough one. The original Operation Flashpoint GOTY game was one of the greatest 'realistic', tactical, sans-health bar FPS games of all time, with two fantastic expansions which both added huge amounts of content to the game (in much the same way Morrowind was improved by Tribunal and Bloodmoon) and a wonderful gameplay style that gave the game tremendous replayability and gave the player tremendous scope to imagine the world around them.Of course, after that original title the companies that were responsible for the game split up - Bohemia Interactive making the ARMA series (eternally disapointing in kind of the same way Gothic was: just not refined, polished, bug-free or fun enough to match the technological ambition) and Codemasters making this game.Dragon Rising was many years in the making, and while you can say that in certain ways it was a better shooter than the ARMA titles, you can say that it was nevertheless dissapointing and an inferior title to the original OpFlash in terms of how it contrasted with the titles already available.If we are to compare this game with ARMA then you might say that the game is a bit more stable, the missions a bit more cinematic and well paced, the guns a bit more realistic and satisfying to use. These advantages are real and enjoyable, but none of them represent industry leading iterations of the features - the original OpFlash lead the industry in map size, replayability, freedom, difficulty (if you so desired) and scope, but Dragon Rising doesn't really set the world alight in any one way.This does have to do with the bugs that, while not as annoying as in ARMA 2, for example, are still present. I once played a mission where a tank somehow got stuck to my soldier by an invisible, 10 meter pole. no kidding, I walked around the map with a many tonne tank spinning wildly ten meters above my head, smacking and clattering into the ground incessantly whenever I tried to get in a vehicle but, somewhat disapointingly, refusing to crush the squad mates that I tired to hard to splatter. Another time I had to give up on an entire playthrough as a certain mission bugged and was simply impossible to complete.The zones are still big, the soliders still responsive to orders, the enemies still reasonably deadly, but the island of Skira fails to burst into life in the same way the original OpFlash island of Everon did, largely because the game is let down by instability and unconvincing scenarios. It is a huge shame that this game failed, and while some admirable advertising almost convinced me to give Red River a go it was apparently even worse than DR, and as such sadly I fear we must lay this game to rest.I am reminded of the classic xBox shooter BLACK. Quite forgotten now, it had a really polished feel and really immersive, solid missions. It is perhaps where the ingredients that would have made Dragon Rising a really good game snuck off to.I still recommend this game, because it is better than ARMA 2 for as long as it lasts before it bugs out, and it just has a better title, let's face it.

												OFDR is an attempt by Codemaster to reviveits Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis, originally developed by Bohemia Interactive (who created their own "Arma" franchise). Using their own "EGO" engine, OFDR is an attempt to bring back the "sandbox military shooter" genre, in trying to get away from the tightly scripted experience of MOH or COD franchise. The result is a bit hit and miss, due to unforgiving difficulty, a tightly scripted experience on an open map, and clunky interface that was not even optimized for gamepad. Set on a fictional island just off Russia, which has the potential of large oil reserves, China, with some historical claims, chose to invade it for the oil to fulfill its own energy needs. Russia, busy with its problems, requested US for help, and US marines landed, and soo ncame into direct conflict with the People's Liberation Army. You will get to play two characters... a Marine Sgt with his own fireteam, and a special forces lieutenant leading his own fireteam. They have different missions on different part of the island, but together they will find a way to kick the PLA off the island. The game is realistic in that you can be wounded by a single bullet, and a head shot will likely kill you. You will need to use the medpack on yourself to staunch the bleeding (else you'll fade out and die), and/or summon the fireteam medic (or anyone else) to bandage you. However, the interface to do so is clumsy and impossible to use during combat. Same with grenades. You have them, but throwing them is a real PITA. The game does retail a lot of the open feel. If you can get at a vehicle, you can probably drive it. A jeep, sure. Tank or APC? No problem. Helicopter? Why not, if you catch one on the ground. Killing armor, on the other hand, is a different problem, as clearly they are invulnerable to your bullets, and you have to find anti-armor weapons (Queen Bee AT rocket, Javelin AT missile, etc.) . And you will occasionally get to shoot Stinger or Strela SAM at helicopters. The actual shooting, however, leaves much to be desired. You will barely spot the enemy at all, even through the various target scopes, unless you happen across a sniper rifle (usually by killing an enemy sniper, or special ammo crates). There's also plenty of foliage and terrain features. Add it to a very... bland color pallete (it's almost all autumn yellow) and you'll NEVER spot the enemies without a little help from the threat indicator (which is only active at the "easy" difficulty level).  And no, there's no "radar" showing you where the enemies are. This is a sim, not a "game". The missions are long and the progress saved at checkpoints. However, the checkpoints are not always placed at logical spots, and you often don't know what exactly you did wrong last playthrough. So you end up repeating the checkpoint over and over until you throw your controller through the monitor. The missions also fail to allow the open-sandbox style map to work its magic, as most of the missions are tightly scripted and often with a TIME LIMIT, such as "you must eliminate the SAM teams before our own gunships arrive in X minutes". Obviously there's going to be a ton of enemies between you and the SAM teams, all wanting to shoot you dead. All in all, OFDR is extremely disappointing. It has plenty of potential, as its sequel, OF:Red River showed. However, the execution is marred by timed mission triggers, impossibility of acquiring targets in the scopes, and very clunky interface, even on a gamepad.

												I only would say "Yes, I recommend this game." now because of it's low price, and only to those who've poured goodly ammount of hours into Arma products, or people who are looking for a slight in-between of arcade-meets-try-hard-simulator. This IS the continuation of Operation Flashpoint, to a degree. So when Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crises was released early in 2001, the developers of it Bohemia Interactive had a bit of a falling out with the publisher, Codemasters.The title remained operation flashpoint, and the engine that was operation flashpoint 1 was redeveloped, Bohemia Ineteractive then went in the direction they did with ARMA 1 2 & 3, Take on Helicopters, Take on Mars I also believe. The Arma franchise went foreward and Codemasters put money into other products as after a few more OFP titles they didn't make the haul in cash they were looking for- probably for the best actually, the later titles were no better then this if that.This is almost a Battlefield meets Arma 1.5/2 engine, it still is very much like Arma or Operation Flashpoint in terms of controls, 'jankiness', try-hard realism, but some aspects of the game were made a lot arcadey, forgiving, and catering to the players action packed experiance instead of getting sniped from hard to see soldiers in fields at dusk (though thats still likely to happen in this engine). If you do enjoy campaigns in the Arma engine, or you enjoy playing with the mission editors- Mission Editor is pretty much the same it was to Operation Flashpoint if memory serves me right-, and you have a few bucks to blow, this game can give you some more arcade like hours of fun then arma can, though for content it really is no replacement!

												I never got around to play the first Operation Flashpoint, so I can't really compare this to its predecessor. And I can say that I've tried ARMA2 and ARMA3 and think they are a little TOO hardcore for my taste. With that said, Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising are a good mixture between "regular" military FPS games and hardcore military simulators just like the ARMA series.The game takes place on the fictional island of Skira, based on the island Kiska which is located in Alaska. The Global Economic Crisis makes China seize control of the island from Russia, just to be able to grab the oil on the island. Of course, the russians are not very fond of this and they put their army on taking back the army from the PLA (People's Liberation Army). As they already encounter the PLA on the chinese main land, they call to the USA to retake Skira for them. And so... you're playing as two different squad leaders in the struggle of reclaiming Skira. Nothing too fancy.I thought it was a really good game and the player must be careful when playing, can't play it like a Call of Duty game where you just run in to the fire fight and kill everyone "Rambo style". No, that'll result in death very quickly. Instead, the player need to take it slow, think about what route to take and if he/she really need to kill that one soldier, why not go around the enemy? 												- INTRO -(IF YOU WANT TO PLAY MULTIPLAYER HIT ME UP, I HOST) I originally played this game extensively on Xbox360 since its release in 2009 and have comfortably logged over 1300+ hours on that, 120+ hours PC on another Steam account, and recently purchased it for this account.  Alongside this series I have played ArmA since the ArmA II release for a similar amount of time of various accounts.  I will start with the bad since that is most important.  Keep in mind this game is dear to me but I know where it lacks.- THE BAD (and meh) -For starters I used to play when Codemasters had the servers up for multiplayer but unfortunately they have pulled the plug many years ago.  I must use Hamachi, a VPN LAN service, to play with friends in multiplayer.  Codemasters promised far more than was delivered and bailed on the project for the racing series.  There is little mod support and most of them only function with V 1.00 not V 1.02 which is purchased through steam.Akin to ArmA II and earlier the AI vehicle pathfinding is awful.  They try to move in a direct line to the waypoint you have set.  If they encounter an obstruction, even a tiny one, they ram it and continue trying to drive forward.  For a game of this complexity and for its time I guess I understand.  No mods were ever developed to fix this.This game feels almost identical on PC as it does to the Xbox360 release.  I think this game even on PC works ideally with an Xbox 360 controller.  Here is the where the problem arises...This games only supports keyboard and mouse or an Xbox 360 controller.  You are unable to use any other sort of controller or flightsicks.  I believe most of these issues are because the game was optimized for console release.Due to limited support from Codemasters there are not too many missions.  To their credit, the missions they did release are well crafted and fully functional.  The only notable issues I have seen is in the campaign mission Hip Shot (night raid on the fuel depot) in multiplayer where the diversion side objective does not function properly.- THE GOOD - Stunning visuals and cinematic audio make this game quite intense.  I wish there were some sound mods to improve the realism of incoming rounds but it is a trivial issue.  The dirt splatters, JDAM strikes, smoke plooms, and fire were quite impressive for its time.  Even to this day I am awed by the visuals and audio!  The crushed black edges and use of filters give the illusion of cleaner graphics and are easy on the eyes.Gameplay is fairly pleasant.  When people ask what OFP:DR is like I tell them it is the bridge between Battlefield and ArmA.  It has some aspects of realism that do add a challenge but not too much to the point there is a steep learning curve.  I absolutely LOVE the command radial!  Character movement is fluid considering the nature of the game, I do wish they had a lean option.  Helicopter controls are decent although the physics are a not exactly simulation.When you use Hamachi or some other virtual LAN multiplayer is a blast.  You have a fair amount of control over respawns and difficulty.  REMEMBER, THE OFP:DR INTERNET SERVERS NO LONGER EXIST, YOU MUST USE A VIRTUAL LAN SERVICE.- CONCLUSION - I believe this game receives unnecessary flak from the community.  I feel this is because it did not live up to its original expectations and have a rough launch but none the less now is an awesome game.  Especially in 2016 $10 is hard to go wrong and this game is worth every penny.  If you wish to play multiplayer download Hamachi VPN and invite your friends.  I love ArmA and other simulation type games and have to say this is a worthy addition to that category of gaming.  I have picked up and dropped many titles but OFP:DR has a place in my heart and has not sign of dying for me anytime soon.

												Yes I review a game here everyone else had played years ago and I won't state anything new here, too. I left the series after the very first OF, my computer back than was struggling with the graphics but the game left a lasting impression on me- especially the mission editor was great. I am not a multiplayer guy, online MP is to tough for me, LANs just don't happen anymore. So I am just testing and reviewing the solo player mission here.What can I say:It is hard. Maybe I just suck, but I rarely have played a game that is so frustrating. The realism is good, although I think the ability of your team mates and your enemy differs a lot. My team rarely hits anything while the enemy snipes you from 500+ meters, whether you lie down or you run zigzag. I like the AI (they flank you when you camp or throw grenades) but all tactics on my side seem to be completely bugged or useless. Telling your team to flank or to suppress simply makes them act stupid (they advance but don't fire OR they start firing wildly but stand still). The team is great at spotting enemies, often long before I see them, but they completely fail at shooting/hitting them. Even a soldier standing still facing his rear side or non moving targets at 25m distance! Then it seems to be impossible to sneak up at someone. I tried at night, crawling through high grass towards an enemy outpost overwatching the other direction. At 25m he turned around and started firing at me. And this triggered the alarm for ALL troops in the mission area. How did he radio/set the alarm while turning around and shooting?It is good that you cannot sneak/knife through entire missions, but the missions rely on stealth/avoiding contact or firefights. The game spils this everytime you try. It gets pretty annoying restarting missions simply because the game balancing is crap. Everytime you make a tiny mistake (although you did what was expected) combat helicopters show up and blast you to kingdom come. Or entire companies of enemies appear out of thin air and encirlce your position.I play this game on a medium laptop with just ok settings. This does not work well. Zoom and vision are pretty realistic, enemies at 200m are a handful of pixels only. This game only works well on full resolution and large monitors. You should also be able to have good to max video settings at hand, otherwise the surroundings are rendered so roughly that it is almost impossible to tell enemies from objects.This is not an action game. In large parts it asks you to crawl/sneak through forest or brush land, avoiding being seen. You advance a few dozen meters, then check area with your binoculars. Changing weapon to binocular and back takes awfully long, though.You can not choose weapons/equipment freely for your missions. You will often wish you could bring a sniper rifle along, but you are not allowed to. You will run out of ammo fast, especially if you don't switch to single fire always. Calling for ammo resupply does not work. Your team mates won't share a single mag with you. Looting dead enemies only works if you get to them fast. They disappear after a few moments. Usually they only carry a minimum equipment set (often their rifle has a single mag left, no spare magazines). I wonder how they can shoot at you endlessly while alive, but when they die their ammunition magically vanishes...Teammates in vehicles don't fight. They do mount the MG on a jeep while you drive, but don't expect them to use it. Regardless of commands you have given them. They are also not able to drive a vehicle while you mount the weapons... pretty much sucks.It feels like this game was made for multiplayer and got a handful of bugged and annoying solo missions attached to it later.It was ok for 10€ but I was pretty disappointed by it. I have to check out the editor options yet, but so far I could not find anything that compares to the easy to use and flexible editor from the original game.

												This game more or less butchered everything I liked about the original Flashpoint. It wasn't a bad game by itself, but Arma: Cold War Assault is vastly superior. The combat mechanics in this game were a little iffy; the controls were confused, the weapons highly indistinguishable from one another. The missions were boring, tedious, and to a large degree impossible. More often than not, I felt that, once again, my comrades and I were simply being dropped into a meat-grinder. This isn't the original Flashpoint, where you would die a lot from accurate AK fire 500 meters away (with a single headshot, no less), and learn from your mistakes. In this game, it felt too much like you would get killed by the most BS shot ever, or more often because your idiot teammates didn't come heal you (problem with the AI). Story is non-existent. PLA as the enemy was a good choice, as I was able to get my hands on some juicy weaponry (their firearms are vastly superior, particularly the Type 81 and the Type 76, both of which were used to mow me and my team down on countless occasions). The vehicles are unusable in this game- for that ALONE I take twenty points off, because that was flawlessly executed in the original game, only to be completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed up here. Hasn't Codemasters ever heard of "If it ain't broke, don't fix it"?I recommmend this game, but with a warning: prepare to be frustrated. What's worse, unlike the frustration-prone OG Flashpoint, the victories aren't nearly as satisfying. So in the end, what's it all for?7.5/10
